1â†’# PRD JSON Schema
     2â†’
     3â†’This document defines the canonical JSON structure for Product Requirements Documents (PRDs) in the Maven Flow system. All tools and agents must use this schema.
     4â†’
     5â†’## JSON Structure
     6â†’
     7â†’```json
     8â†’{
     9â†’  "project": "string - Project name from PRD title",
    10â†’  "branchName": "string - Git branch name in format: flow/feature-name-kebab-case",
    11â†’  "description": "string - Brief one-line description of the feature",
    12â†’  "memorialFile": "string - Path to memorial file: docs/memorial-feature-name.txt",
    13â†’  "relatedMemorials": [
    14â†’    "string - Paths to related memorial files"
    15â†’  ],
    16â†’  "userStories": [
    17â†’    {
    18â†’      "id": "string - User story ID: US-001, US-002, etc.",
    19â†’      "title": "string - Short title describing the story",
    20â†’      "description": "string - Full user story: As a [user], I want [feature] so that [benefit]",
    21â†’      "acceptanceCriteria": [
    22â†’        "string - Verifiable criterion 1",
    23â†’        "string - Verifiable criterion 2",
    24â†’        "string - Typecheck passes"
    25â†’      ],
    26â†’      "mavenSteps": [number, number],
    27â†’      "mcpTools": {
    28â†’        "step1": ["mcp-name-1", "mcp-name-2"],
    29â†’        "step7": ["mcp-name-3"]
    30â†’      },
    31â†’      "priority": number,
    32â†’      "passes": boolean,
    33â†’      "notes": "string"
    34â†’    }
    35â†’  ]
    36â†’}
    37â†’```
    38â†’
    39â†’## Field Specifications
    40â†’
    41â†’### Root Level
    42â†’
    43â†’| Field | Type | Required | Description |
    44â†’|-------|------|----------|-------------|
    45â†’| `project` | string | Yes | Project name, typically from PRD title |
    46â†’| `branchName` | string | Yes | Git branch name for this feature (format: `flow/feature-name`) |
    47â†’| `description` | string | Yes | One-line summary of what this feature does |
    48â†’| `memorialFile` | string | Yes | Path to this feature's memorial file |
    49â†’| `relatedMemorials` | array | Yes | List of related memorial file paths |
    50â†’| `userStories` | array | Yes | Array of user story objects (minimum 1) |
    51â†’
    52â†’### User Story Object
    53â†’
    54â†’| Field | Type | Required | Description |
    55â†’|-------|------|----------|-------------|
    56â†’| `id` | string | Yes | Story identifier: US-001, US-002, etc. |
    57â†’| `title` | string | Yes | Short descriptive title |
    58â†’| `description` | string | Yes | Full user story format: "As a [user], I want [feature] so that [benefit]" |
    59â†’| `acceptanceCriteria` | array | Yes | List of verifiable criteria. Must include "Typecheck passes" |
    60â†’| `mavenSteps` | array | Yes | Array of step numbers (1-10). Never empty. |
    61â†’| `mcpTools` | object | Yes | Step-based MCP tool mapping. Use `{}` if none. |
    62â†’| `priority` | number | Yes | Priority order (lower = higher priority). Must be â‰¥ 1. |
    63â†’| `passes` | boolean | Yes | Story completion status. Always `false` initially. |
    64â†’| `notes` | string | Yes | Implementation notes. Always empty string initially. |
    65â†’
    66â†’## Maven Steps Reference
    67â†’
    68â†’Every user story must specify which Maven Flow steps are required:
    69â†’
    70â†’| Step | Agent | Purpose |
    71â†’|------|-------|---------|
    72â†’| 1 | development | Foundation/UI from scratch |
    73â†’| 2 | development | Package manager changes (npmâ†’pnpm) |
    74â†’| 3 | refactor | Feature structure changes |
    75â†’| 4 | refactor | Modularization (when >300 lines) |
    76â†’| 5 | quality | Type safety enforcement (no 'any' types) |
    77â†’| 6 | refactor | UI centralization (@shared/ui) |
    78â†’| 7 | development | Data layer/backend implementation |
    79â†’| 8 | security | Authentication/authorization integration |
    80â†’| 9 | development | MCP integration |
    81â†’| 10 | security | Security hardening & error handling |
    82â†’
    83â†’### Step Mapping by Story Type
    84â†’
    85â†’- **Database changes** â†’ `[1, 7]`
    86â†’- **UI component** â†’ `[5, 6]`
    87â†’- **Backend API** â†’ `[1, 7, 10]`
    88â†’- **Auth flow** â†’ `[1, 7, 8, 10]`
    89â†’- **Full feature** â†’ `[1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 10]`
    90â†’
    91â†’## MCP Tools Format
    92â†’
    93â†’The `mcpTools` object maps step numbers to MCP server names:
    94â†’
    95â†’```json
    96â†’{
    97â†’  "mcpTools": {
    98â†’    "step1": ["supabase"],
    99â†’    "step7": ["supabase", "web-search-prime"]
   100â†’  }
   101â†’}
   102â†’```
   103â†’
   104â†’**Rules:**
   105â†’- Only list MCP **server names** (e.g., "supabase"), not individual tools
   106â†’- Use step-based keys: "step1", "step2", etc.
   107â†’- Use empty object `{}` if no MCPs needed for this story
   108â†’
   109â†’### Common MCPs
   110â†’
   111â†’| MCP Name | When to Use |
   112â†’|----------|-------------|
   113â†’| `supabase` | Steps 1, 7, 8, 10 - Database/auth operations |
   114â†’| `web-search-prime` | All steps - Web searches |
   115â†’| `chrome-devtools` | Testing - Browser automation |
   116â†’| `4-5v-mcp` | All steps - Image analysis |
   117â†’
   118â†’## Story Sizing Rules
   119â†’
   120â†’Each story MUST be completable in ONE iteration (one context window).
   121â†’
   122â†’### RIGHT-sized stories:
   123â†’- Add database column + migration
   124â†’- Add UI component to existing page
   125â†’- Update server action with new logic
   126â†’- Implement single API endpoint
   127â†’
   128â†’### TOO BIG (split these):
   129â†’- "Build entire dashboard" â†’ Split into: schema, queries, UI, filters
   130â†’- "Add authentication" â†’ Split into: schema, middleware, login UI, sessions
   131â†’- "Create CRUD system" â†’ Split into: Create, Read, Update, Delete separately
   132â†’
   133â†’## Story Ordering
   134â†’
   135â†’Stories should be ordered by dependency:
   136â†’
   137â†’1. **Schema/database changes** (foundational)
   138â†’2. **Server actions/backend logic** (depend on schema)
   139â†’3. **UI components** (depend on backend)
   140â†’4. **Dashboard/summary views** (depend on everything)
   141â†’
   142â†’## Acceptance Criteria Rules
   143â†’
   144â†’All criteria must be **verifiable**:
   145â†’
   146â†’âœ“ Good: "Add status column with default 'pending'"
   147â†’âœ“ Good: "Redirect unauthenticated users to /login"
   148â†’âœ“ Good: "Typecheck passes"
   149â†’
   150â†’âœ— Bad: "Works correctly"
   151â†’âœ— Bad: "User friendly interface"
   152â†’âœ— Bad: "Error handling"
   153â†’
   154â†’**Required:** Every story MUST include `"Typecheck passes"` in acceptance criteria.
   155â†’
   156â†’## Example Complete JSON
   157â†’
   158â†’```json
   159â†’{
   160â†’  "project": "Artboard System",
   161â†’  "branchName": "flow/vector-canvas",
   162â†’  "description": "Infinite vector canvas with pan, zoom, and object manipulation",
   163â†’  "memorialFile": "docs/memorial-vector-canvas.txt",
   164â†’  "relatedMemorials": [
   165â†’    "docs/memorial-workspace-file-management.txt",
   166â†’    "docs/maven-flow-wrapper.txt"
   167â†’  ],
   168â†’  "userStories": [
   169â†’    {
   170â†’      "id": "US-001",
   171â†’      "title": "Database schema for canvas objects",
   172â†’      "description": "As a developer, I need a database schema to store canvas objects so that users can save their work",
   173â†’      "acceptanceCriteria": [
   174â†’        "Create canvas_objects table with id, type, x, y, width, height, rotation, properties columns",
   175â†’        "Add indexes on workspace_id and object_type",
   176â†’        "Create migration file in supabase/migrations/",
   177â†’        "Typecheck passes"
   178â†’      ],
   179â†’      "mavenSteps": [1, 7],
   180â†’      "mcpTools": {
   181â†’        "step1": ["supabase"],
   182â†’        "step7": ["supabase"]
   183â†’      },
   184â†’      "priority": 1,
   185â†’      "passes": false,
   186â†’      "notes": ""
   187â†’    },
   188â†’    {
   189â†’      "id": "US-002",
   190â†’      "title": "Canvas object component",
   191â†’      "description": "As a user, I want to see and manipulate canvas objects so that I can create designs",
   192â†’      "acceptanceCriteria": [
   193â†’        "Create CanvasObject component with selection, move, resize handles",
   194â†’        "Implement keyboard shortcuts (Delete, Ctrl+D for duplicate)",
   195â†’        "Add z-index management (bring to front/send to back)",
   196â†’        "Typecheck passes"
   197â†’      ],
   198â†’      "mavenSteps": [5, 6],
   199â†’      "mcpTools": {},
   200â†’      "priority": 2,
   201â†’      "passes": false,
   202â†’      "notes": ""
   203â†’    }
   204â†’  ]
   205â†’}
   206â†’```
   207â†’
   208â†’## Validation Checklist
   209â†’
   210â†’When generating or consuming PRD JSON files, verify:
   211â†’
   212â†’- [ ] All required fields present
   213â†’- [ ] `mavenSteps` is never empty
   214â†’- [ ] `mcpTools` object exists (use `{}` if empty)
   215â†’- [ ] Every story has "Typecheck passes" in acceptance criteria
   216â†’- [ ] `passes` is `false` for all new stories
   217â†’- [ ] `notes` is empty string for new stories
   218â†’- [ ] Acceptance criteria are verifiable (not vague)
   219â†’- [ ] Stories ordered by dependency
   220â†’- [ ] Each story completable in one iteration
   221â†’- [ ] MCP names only (not individual tools)
   222â†’- [ ] Step-based keys in mcpTools ("step1", "step7", etc.)
   223â†’
   224â†’## File Naming Convention
   225â†’
   226â†’PRD JSON files must follow this naming pattern:
   227â†’- Pattern: `prd-{feature-name}.json`
   228â†’- Example: `prd-vector-canvas.json`
   229â†’- Location: `docs/` directory
   230â†’
   231â†’These files are generated from `prd-{feature-name}.md` markdown PRDs.
   232â†’

   916â†’## MCP Tool Assignment
   917â†’
   918â†’### What are MCPs?
   919â†’MCPs (Model Context Protocol) extend Claude with external tools like databases, web search, and browser automation.
   920â†’
   921â†’### How MCP Assignment Works
   922â†’
   923â†’**1. PRD specifies MCPs per step:**
   924â†’```json
   925â†’{
   926â†’  "id": "US-001",
   927â†’  "mavenSteps": [1, 7],
   928â†’  "mcpTools": {
   929â†’    "step1": ["supabase"],
   930â†’    "step7": ["supabase", "web-search-prime"]
   931â†’  }
   932â†’}
   933â†’```
   934â†’
   935â†’**2. Flow tells agent which MCPs to use:**
   936â†’```
   937â†’*** CRITICAL: MCP TOOLS INSTRUCTION ***
   938â†’You MUST use the Supabase MCP tools for ALL database operations.
   939â†’SCAN FIRST - Use MCP to list/check what exists in the database BEFORE making changes.
   940â†’Query the database DIRECTLY using Supabase MCP tools.
   941â†’
   942â†’Story: US-001, Step 1
   943â†’MCPs: supabase
   944â†’```
   945â†’
   946â†’**3. Agent uses those MCPs:**
   947â†’- Checks if MCPs are available in their tool set
   948â†’- Uses MCP tools directly to query database, run migrations, etc.
   949â†’- Falls back to standard tools only if MCPs unavailable
   950â†’
   951â†’### Available MCPs
   952â†’
   953â†’| MCP Name | Purpose | Steps Used For |
   954â†’|----------|---------|----------------|
   955â†’| supabase | Database operations | 1, 7, 8, 10 |
   956â†’| web-search-prime | Research, documentation | All steps |
   957â†’| web-reader | Read web content | All steps |
   958â†’| chrome-devtools | Browser testing | Testing phases |
   959â†’| playwright | Browser automation | Testing phases |
   960â†’| vercel | Deployment to Vercel | 9 |
   961â†’| wrangler | Deployment to Cloudflare | 9 |
   962â†’| figma | Design work | 11 |
   963â†’
   964â†’**MCP Usage Rules:**
   965â†’- **SCAN FIRST** - Always list/check what exists before making changes
   966â†’- **Query directly** - Use MCP tools, don't read migration files
   967â†’- **Verify in actual database** - Don't trust type files, verify with MCP
   968â†’- **Fall back gracefully** - Use standard tools if MCP unavailable

  1002â†’1. **Create PRD** - Use the `flow-prd` skill to generate requirements
  1003â†’2. **Convert to JSON** - Use the `flow-convert` skill to create `docs/prd-[feature-name].json`
  1004â†’3. **Start Flow** - Run `/flow start` to begin autonomous iteration
  1005â†’4. **Monitor Progress** - Use `/flow status` to check all PRDs
  1006â†’5. **Review Results** - Each story is committed separately with descriptive messages
  1007â†’
  1008â†’## How It Works
  1009â†’
  1010â†’### Multi-PRD Processing
  1011â†’
  1012â†’When you run `/flow start`:
  1013â†’
  1014â†’1. **Scan Phase:** The flow scans `docs/` for all `prd-*.json` files
  1015â†’2. **Priority Phase:** For each PRD, checks completion status:
  1016â†’   - Loads JSON and checks if all stories have `passes: true`
  1017â†’   - Identifies PRDs with incomplete stories (`passes: false`)
  1018â†’3. **Selection Phase:** Picks the first incomplete PRD (alphabetically by filename)
  1019â†’4. **Iteration Phase:** Processes that PRD's stories one by one:
  1020â†’   - Reads PRD JSON and picks highest priority story where `passes: false`
  1021â†’   - Reads story's `mavenSteps` array
  1022â†’   - **Spawns specialist agents directly** (one per mavenStep)
  1023â†’   - Waits for each agent to complete
  1024â†’   - Runs quality checks
  1025â†’   - Commits changes
  1026â†’   - Updates PRD to `passes: true`
  1027â†’   - Appends learnings to progress file
  1028â†’5. **Completion Phase:** When PRD is complete (all `passes: true`):
  1029â†’   - Marks PRD as complete
  1030â†’   - Moves to next incomplete PRD
  1031â†’   - Repeats iteration phase
  1032â†’6. **Final Phase:** When all PRDs are complete:
  1033â†’   - Outputs completion summary
  1034â†’
  1035â†’### Maven Step to Agent Mapping
  1036â†’
  1037â†’The `/flow` command maps each step in the story's `mavenSteps` array to the appropriate specialist agent:
  1038â†’
  1039â†’| Maven Step | Agent Type | Task subagent_type | Description |
  1040â†’|------------|------------|-------------------|-------------|
  1041â†’| 1 | Foundation | development-agent | Import UI with mock data or create from scratch |
  1042â†’| 2 | Package Manager | development-agent | Convert npm â†’ pnpm |
  1043â†’| 3 | Feature Structure | refactor-agent | Restructure to feature-based folder structure |
  1044â†’| 4 | Modularization | refactor-agent | Modularize components >300 lines |
  1045â†’| 5 | Type Safety | quality-agent | Type safety - no 'any' types, @ aliases |
  1046â†’| 6 | UI Centralization | refactor-agent | Centralize UI components to @shared/ui |
  1047â†’| 7 | Data Layer | development-agent | Centralized data layer with backend setup |
  1048â†’| 8 | Auth Integration | security-agent | Firebase + Supabase authentication flow |
  1049â†’| 9 | MCP Integration | development-agent | MCP integrations (web-search, web-reader, chrome, expo, supabase) |
  1050â†’| 10 | Security & Error Handling | security-agent | Security and error handling |
  1051â†’| 11 | Mobile Design | design-agent | Professional UI/UX for Expo/React Native (optional) |

  1140â†’## Feature-Based Architecture

  1293â†’## Required MCPs
  1294â†’
  1295â†’### Mandatory MCPs for Maven Flow
  1296â†’
  1297â†’Maven Flow requires specific MCP servers to be configured for autonomous development and testing to function correctly.
  1298â†’
  1299â†’#### Two Mandatory MCPs
  1300â†’
  1301â†’**1. Supabase MCP (MANDATORY)**
  1302â†’- **Purpose:** Direct database access, schema verification, migrations, type generation
  1303â†’- **Why mandatory:**
  1304â†’  - Agents need to QUERY the actual database (not read files)
  1305â†’  - Agents need to VERIFY tables and schema exist
  1306â†’  - Agents need to CREATE tables and run migrations
  1307â†’  - Agents need to GENERATE TypeScript types from live schema
  1308â†’- **Without Supabase MCP:**
  1309â†’  - Agents will fall back to reading migration files (doesn't verify actual database)
  1310â†’  - Agents will create migration scripts manually (error-prone)
  1311â†’  - Agents cannot verify what's actually in the database
  1312â†’
  1313â†’**2. chrome-devtools MCP (MANDATORY)**
  1314â†’- **Purpose:** Live browser testing, console log reading, application verification
  1315â†’- **Why mandatory:**
  1316â†’  - testing-agent MUST open the application to test features
  1317â†’  - Agents MUST read console logs to find errors
  1318â†’  - Agents MUST verify UI works in real browser
  1319â†’  - Agents MUST test user flows end-to-end
  1320â†’- **Without chrome-devtools MCP:**
  1321â†’  - testing-agent cannot test the application
  1322â†’  - Console errors go undetected
  1323â†’  - Features cannot be verified in browser
  1324â†’  - Testing becomes manual and incomplete
  1325â†’

  1379â†’## Testing & Consolidation
  1380â†’
  1381â†’### Workflow: Test â†’ Log â†’ Consolidate â†’ Fix
  1382â†’
  1383â†’Maven Flow includes a systematic testing and error consolidation workflow to ensure quality.
  1384â†’
  1385â†’### Step 1: Test (`/flow test`)
  1386â†’
  1387â†’**Purpose:** Comprehensive automated testing of all completed features
  1388â†’
  1389â†’**What happens:**
  1390â†’1. Reads PRD to find completed stories (where `passes: true`)
  1391â†’2. Starts dev server: `pnpm dev`
  1392â†’3. Opens application using chrome-devtools MCP
  1393â†’4. Tests user signup/login with standard test credentials
  1394â†’5. Tests each completed feature's acceptance criteria
  1395â†’6. Checks console for errors (logs ALL errors found)
  1396â†’7. Tests navigation, forms, data display
  1397â†’8. Creates error log at `docs/errors-[feature-name].md`
  1398â†’
  1399â†’**Standard Test User:**
  1400â†’- Email: `revccnt@gmail.com`
  1401â†’- Password: `Elishiba!90`
  1402â†’
  1403â†’**What gets tested:**
  1404â†’- User authentication (signup, login, logout)
  1405â†’- All completed stories' acceptance criteria
  1406â†’- Console errors (JavaScript, network, API)
  1407â†’- UI functionality
  1408â†’- Navigation between pages
  1409â†’- Form submissions
  1410â†’- Data display
  1411â†’
  1412â†’**Example:**
  1413â†’```bash
  1414â†’/flow test task-priority
  1415â†’```
  1416â†’
  1417â†’**Output:**
  1418â†’- Shows which features are being tested
  1419â†’- Reports errors in real-time
  1420â†’- Creates error log markdown file
  1421â†’- Summary with error counts by severity
  1422â†’
  1423â†’### Step 2: Review Error Log
  1424â†’
  1425â†’**Error log format:** `docs/errors-[feature-name].md`
  1426â†’
  1427â†’**Each error includes:**
  1428â†’- Story ID (US-XXX)
  1429â†’- Severity (Critical / High / Medium / Low)
  1430â†’- Error type (Console Error / Network Error / UI Issue)
  1431â†’- Error message (exact text from console)
  1432â†’- Steps to reproduce
  1433â†’- Expected vs actual behavior
  1434â†’- Related file references
  1435â†’- Suggested fixes
  1436â†’
  1437â†’**Example error log entry:**
  1438â†’```markdown
  1439â†’## Error 1
  1440â†’
  1441â†’**Story:** US-003 - Add priority selector
  1442â†’**Feature:** Task creation form
  1443â†’**Severity:** High
  1444â†’
  1445â†’**Error Type:** Console Error
  1446â†’
  1447â†’**Error Message:**
  1448â†’```
  1449â†’Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'map' of undefined
  1450â†’at PrioritySelector.tsx:24
  1451â†’```
  1452â†’
  1453â†’**Steps to Reproduce:**
  1454â†’1. Navigate to /tasks/create
  1455â†’2. Click on "Priority" dropdown
  1456â†’3. Observe error in console
  1457â†’
  1458â†’**Expected Behavior:**
  1459â†’Priority dropdown shows options: Low, Medium, High, Urgent
  1460â†’
  1461â†’**Actual Behavior:**
  1462â†’Application crashes, dropdown doesn't render
  1463â†’
  1464â†’**Related Files:**
  1465â†’- File: src/features/tasks/components/PrioritySelector.tsx
  1466â†’- Line: 24
  1467â†’- Component: PrioritySelector
  1468â†’
  1469â†’**Suggested Fix:**
  1470â†’Check that priorities prop is defined before mapping. Add default value or null check.
  1471â†’```
  1472â†’
  1473â†’### Step 3: Consolidate (`/flow consolidate`)
  1474â†’
  1475â†’**Purpose:** Fix ONLY the specific errors found during testing (NOT reimplement features)
  1476â†’
  1477â†’**What happens:**
  1478â†’1. Reads error log from `docs/errors-[feature-name].md`
  1479â†’2. Parses each error to identify:
  1480â†’   - Which story (US-XXX) has the error
  1481â†’   - Which step/mavenStep needs to be re-run
  1482â†’   - What the specific error is
  1483â†’3. For each error:
  1484â†’   - Spawns appropriate specialist agent (development, quality, security, etc.)
  1485â†’   - Tells agent exactly what error to fix
  1486â†’   - Waits for fix to be applied
  1487â†’4. Re-tests ONLY the fixed item
  1488â†’5. Marks error as resolved in log
  1489â†’6. Continues until all errors fixed
  1490â†’
  1491â†’**What it does NOT do:**
  1492â†’- Does NOT run full mavenSteps again
  1493â†’- Does NOT re-implement completed features
  1494â†’- Does NOT touch working code
  1495â†’- Only fixes the specific errors identified
  1496â†’
  1497â†’**Example:**
  1498â†’```bash
  1499â†’/flow consolidate task-priority
  1500â†’```
  1501â†’
  1502â†’**Output:**
  1503â†’- Shows which errors are being fixed
  1504â†’- Shows which agent is handling each fix
  1505â†’- Commits each fix separately
  1506â†’- Updates error log as fixes are applied
  1507â†’
  1508â†’### Step 4: Re-test
  1509â†’

  1632â†’### Mobile-Specific Features
  1633â†’
  1634â†’#### Offline-First Architecture
  1635â†’All mobile features work offline with automatic sync:
  1636â†’
  1637â†’**Read Pattern:**
  1638â†’1. Check AsyncStorage cache first
  1639â†’2. If fresh (< 5 min), use cached data
  1640â†’3. If missing/stale, fetch from Supabase
  1641â†’4. Update cache and display
  1642â†’
  1643â†’**Write Pattern:**
  1644â†’1. Optimistically update UI immediately
  1645â†’2. If online: Execute immediately
  1646â†’3. If offline: Queue in AsyncStorage
  1647â†’4. When back online: Process queue automatically
  1648â†’
  1649â†’#### Native UI Patterns
  1650â†’Use mobile-specific interactions:
  1651â†’- **Pull-to-refresh** for data reload
  1652â†’- **Swipe actions** for quick actions (delete, complete)
  1653â†’- **Bottom sheets** for options/modals
  1654â†’- **Tab bar** for main navigation
  1655â†’- **Stack navigation** for drilling down
  1656â†’- **Long-press** for context menus
  1657â†’
  1658â†’#### Touch Targets
  1659â†’- **Minimum 44x44 points** for all touch targets (Apple)
  1660â†’- **48x48 dp minimum** for Android
  1661â†’- Adequate spacing between targets
  1662â†’
  1663â†’#### Push Notifications
  1664â†’- Firebase Cloud Messaging for push notifications
  1665â†’- Task assignments, due reminders, status changes
  1666â†’- Background message handling
  1667â†’- Notification channels (Android)

     6â†’# Flow PRD Converter with Memory Loading
     7â†’
     8â†’Converts existing PRDs (markdown) to the `prd.json` format that next-mavens-flow uses for autonomous execution.
     9â†’
    10â†’**NEW: Now loads existing context and analyzes feature relationships.**
    11â†’
    12â†’---
    13â†’
    14â†’## The Job
    15â†’
    16â†’Take a markdown PRD and convert it to `docs/prd-[feature-name].json`. Create `docs/` folder if it doesn't exist.
    17â†’
    18â†’**Important:** Each feature gets its own PRD JSON file. The flow command will scan for all `prd-*.json` files in `docs/` and process incomplete ones.
    19â†’
    20â†’**CRITICAL:** Each story MUST have its own `mcpTools` object specifying which MCPs to use for each Maven step.
    21â†’
    22â†’---
    23â†’
    24â†’## STEP 1: Read the Markdown PRD
    25â†’
    26â†’**Read the input PRD file:**
    27â†’
    28â†’Execute: `cat "$PRD_FILE"`
    29â†’
    30â†’**Extract key information:**
    31â†’- Project name
    32â†’- Branch name
    33â†’- Description
    34â†’- User stories
    35â†’- Related features (from flow-prd.md Step 2.6)
    36â†’- Context from existing features (if included)
    37â†’
    38â†’---
    39â†’
    40â†’## STEP 2: SCAN EXISTING JSON PRDs
    41â†’
    42â†’**CRITICAL: Before creating the JSON PRD, scan for existing PRDs to understand relationships.**
    43â†’
    44â†’Execute: `find docs -name "prd-*.json" -type f | sort`
    45â†’
    46â†’**For each existing PRD found:**
    47â†’
    48â†’1. **Read the PRD** to understand:
    49â†’   - What feature it implements
    50â†’   - Its status (check if all stories have `passes: true`)
    51â†’   - Its relatedPRDs array
    52â†’   - Its consolidatedMemory (if complete)

    54â†’2. **Build a feature map:**

    56â†’   FEATURE_MAP = {
    57â†’     "prd-auth.json": {
    58â†’       name: "User Authentication",
    59â†’       status: "complete" | "incomplete",
    60â†’       related: ["prd-payments.json"],
    61â†’       consolidated: "..."
    62â†’     },
    63â†’     "prd-products.json": {
    64â†’       name: "Product Catalog",
    65â†’       status: "complete",
    66â†’       related: ["prd-orders.json"],
    67â†’       consolidated: "..."
    68â†’     }
    69â†’   }
    70â†’   ```

    78â†’Execute: For each complete PRD, read its `consolidatedMemory` field

    80â†’**Extract and categorize:**

   131â†’## STEP 4: ANALYZE FEATURE RELATIONSHIPS
   132â†’
   133â†’**CRITICAL: Analyze how this PRD relates to existing PRDs.**
   134â†’
   135â†’### 4.1: Extract Relationships from Markdown PRD
   136â†’
   137â†’**From the markdown PRD's "Related Features" section, extract:**
   138â†’
   139â†’**Depends On:**
   140â†’- Feature names that must exist first
   141â†’- Reasons for dependency
   142â†’- Integration points
   143â†’
   144â†’**Will Be Used By:**
   145â†’- Feature names that will depend on this
   146â†’- Reasons for the dependency
   147â†’- Future integration points
   148â†’
   149â†’### 4.2: Cross-Reference with Existing PRDs
   150â†’
   151â†’**For each related feature mentioned in the markdown PRD:**
   152â†’
   153â†’1. **Find the corresponding JSON PRD:**
   154â†’   - If markdown says "auth", find "prd-auth.json"
   155â†’   - If markdown says "products", find "prd-products.json"
   156â†’
   157â†’2. **Verify the PRD exists:**
   158â†’   ```bash
   159â†’   test -f "docs/prd-[feature].json" && echo "EXISTS" || echo "NOT_FOUND"
   160â†’   ```
   161â†’
   162â†’3. **Check the status:**
   163â†’   - Complete: All stories have `passes: true`
   164â†’   - Incomplete: Some stories have `passes: false`
   165â†’
   166â†’4. **Build the relatedPRDs array:**
   167â†’   ```json
   168â†’   {
   169â†’     "relatedPRDs": [
   170â†’       {
   171â†’         "prd": "prd-auth.json",
   172â†’         "type": "depends_on",
   173â†’         "status": "complete",
   174â†’         "reason": "Payments require authenticated users",
   175â†’         "integration": "user sessions, role-based access"
   176â†’       },
   177â†’       {
   178â†’         "prd": "prd-products.json",
   179â†’         "type": "depends_on",
   180â†’         "status": "complete",
   181â†’         "reason": "Payments process product purchases",
   182â†’         "integration": "product pricing, inventory validation"
   183â†’       },
   184â†’       {
   185â†’         "prd": "prd-orders.json",
   186â†’         "type": "depended_by",
   187â†’         "status": "incomplete",
   188â†’         "reason": "Orders will need payment processing",
   189â†’         "integration": "payment status, transaction history"
   190â†’       }
   191â†’     ]
   192â†’   }
   193â†’   ```
   194â†’
   195â†’### 4.3: Validate Relationship Types
   196â†’
   197â†’**Valid relationship types:**
   198â†’- `depends_on`: This PRD depends on the related PRD
   199â†’- `depended_by`: The related PRD depends on this one
   200â†’- `bidirectional`: Mutual dependency (be careful with these!)
   201â†’
   202â†’**Integration categories:**
   203â†’- `authentication`: User auth, roles, permissions
   204â†’- `data`: Data consumption, API calls, shared models
   205â†’- `components`: Shared UI components, utilities
   206â†’- `infrastructure`: Shared infrastructure, services
   207â†’
   208â†’### 4.4: Handle Edge Cases
   209â†’
   210â†’**If a related PRD doesn't exist:**
   211â†’- Add a warning in the JSON PRD's notes field
   212â†’- Example: `WARNING: Related PRD prd-xyz.json not found - may need to be created first`
   213â†’
   214â†’**If circular dependencies detected:**
   215â†’- Add a warning in the notes field
   216â†’- Example: "WARNING: Circular dependency detected with prd-abc.json - review execution order"
   217â†’

   220â†’## STEP 5: VALIDATE MCP AVAILABILITY
   221â†’
   222â†’**CRITICAL: Before assigning MCPs to stories, validate they are available.**
   223â†’
   224â†’### 5.1: Scan for Available MCPs
   225â†’
   226â†’**How to discover available MCPs:**

   267â†’### 5.3: Assign MCPs Based on Availability

   425â†’## MCP Tool Assignment (Story-Level, Step-Based)
   426â†’
   427â†’**CRITICAL ARCHITECTURE DECISION:** MCPs are assigned PER STORY PER STEP, not at the PRD level.
   428â†’
   429â†’**SCAN FIRST - Discover Available MCPs:**
   430â†’
   431â†’**BEFORE assigning any MCPs to stories, you MUST:**
   432â†’
   433â†’1. **Check which MCP servers are available** in the current environment
   434â†’2. **Only assign MCPs that actually exist** - don't guess or assume
   435â†’3. **If unsure, leave mcpTools empty** `{}` rather than guessing wrong
   436â†’
   437â†’**How to Discover Available MCPs:**
   438â†’- Check the user's MCP configuration
   439â†’- Ask the user what MCPs they have configured
   440â†’- Look for common MCP patterns in the project (e.g., if using Supabase, check if supabase MCP is set up)
   441â†’
   442â†’**Why Scan First?**
   443â†’- Prevents assigning MCPs that don't exist
   444â†’- Avoids confusion when agents can't find the MCP
   445â†’- Ensures PRD matches actual environment capabilities
   446â†’
   447â†’**Why Story-Level MCP Assignment?**
   448â†’
   449â†’1. **Context Isolation:** Each story has its own specific MCPs, reducing confusion as context grows
   450â†’2. **Precision:** Flow command tells agents exactly which MCPs to use for each step
   451â†’3. **No Hallucination:** Prevents agents from "forgetting" which MCPs are available in large contexts
   452â†’4. **Granular Control:** Different stories and steps can use different MCPs
   453â†’
   454â†’**How to Assign MCPs to Stories:**
   455â†’
   456â†’When creating a PRD JSON, for each story:
   457â†’
   458â†’1. **Identify which Maven steps** the story requires (see Maven Steps Field section below)
   459â†’2. **For each step**, specify which MCPs to use (ONLY from discovered/available MCPs)
   460â†’3. **List MCPs in `mcpTools` object** with step-based keys (e.g., `step1`, `step7`)
   461â†’
   462â†’**Important:** You only specify the MCP **name**, not individual tools. The agent will automatically discover and use the available tools from that MCP.
   463â†’
   464â†’**Common MCPs (verify these are available before using):**
   465â†’
   466â†’| MCP Name | Use For Steps |
   467â†’|----------|--------------|
   468â†’| supabase | 7, 8, 10 (database operations) |
   469â†’| web-search-prime | All steps (research, documentation) |
   470â†’| web-reader | All steps (reading web content) |
   471â†’| chrome-devtools | Testing (browser automation) |
   472â†’| vercel | 9 (deployment) |
   473â†’| wrangler | 9 (deployment) |
   474â†’| figma | 11 (design) |
   475â†’
   476â†’**Example MCP Assignment:**
   477â†’```json
   478â†’{
   479â†’  "mavenSteps": [1, 7],
   480â†’  "mcpTools": {
   481â†’    "step1": ["supabase"],
   482â†’    "step7": ["supabase", "web-search-prime"]
   483â†’  }
   484â†’}
   485â†’```
   486â†’
   487â†’This tells the flow:
   488â†’- For Step 1: Use supabase MCP
   489â†’- For Step 7: Use supabase MCP and web-search-prime MCP

   494â†’

   508â†’| 8 | security-agent | Auth Integration - Firebase + Supabase authentication flow |

   523â†’| Refactoring existing code | [4, 5] |

   526â†’**Example assignments:**

   562â†’## Story Size: The Number One Rule
   563â†’
   564â†’**Each story must be completable in ONE flow iteration (one context window).**
   565â†’
   566â†’The flow spawns fresh each iteration with no memory of previous work. If a story is too big, the context fills before finishing and produces broken code.
   567â†’
   568â†’### Right-sized stories:
   569â†’- Add a database column and migration

   571â†’- Update a server action with new logic
   572â†’- Add a filter dropdown to a list

   576â†’- "Add authentication" â†’ Split into: schema, middleware, login UI, session handling

   579â†’**Rule of thumb:** If you cannot describe the change in 2-3 sentences, it's too big.

1â†’# ADR-002: Multi-PRD Architecture
     2â†’
     3â†’**Status:** Accepted
     4â†’
     5â†’**Date:** 2025-01-11
     6â†’
     7â†’## Context
     8â†’
     9â†’**Problem:**
    10â†’- Single monolithic PRD files become unwieldy as projects grow
    11â†’- Different features have different development timelines and priorities
    12â†’- Difficult to track progress across multiple independent features
    13â†’- Merging all features into one flow creates complexity
    14â†’
    15â†’**Observed Issues:**
    16â†’- Large PRD files (1000+ lines) are difficult to navigate and maintain
    17â†’- Changes to one feature block progress on others
    18â†’- No clear separation of concerns between features
    19â†’
    20â†’## Decision
    21â†’
    22â†’**Each feature gets its own PRD JSON file: `docs/prd-[feature-name].json`**
    23â†’
    24â†’The flow command automatically scans for all `prd-*.json` files in `docs/` and processes incomplete ones in order.
    25â†’
    26â†’**Architecture:**
    27â†’```
    28â†’docs/
    29â†’â”œâ”€â”€ prd-user-auth.json          # User authentication feature
    30â†’â”œâ”€â”€ prd-task-priority.json      # Task priority feature
    31â†’â”œâ”€â”€ prd-notifications.json      # Notifications feature
    32â†’â”œâ”€â”€ progress-user-auth.txt      # Auth feature progress log
    33â†’â”œâ”€â”€ progress-task-priority.txt  # Priority feature progress log
    34â†’â””â”€â”€ progress-notifications.txt  # Notifications progress log
    35â†’```
    36â†’
    37â†’**Key Principles:**
    38â†’1. **One PRD per feature**: Each feature has its own PRD file
    39â†’2. **Independent execution**: Features can be developed in parallel
    40â†’3. **Automatic discovery**: Flow command scans for all PRD files
    41â†’4. **Priority ordering**: Stories execute in priority order within each PRD
    42â†’
    43â†’## Consequences
    44â†’
    45â†’**Benefits:**
    46â†’- **Isolation**: Each feature is independent, changes don't affect others
    47â†’- **Parallel development**: Multiple features can be developed simultaneously
    48â†’- **Focused scope**: Each PRD is smaller and more manageable
    49â†’- **Progress tracking**: Clear progress per feature via separate progress files
    50â†’- **Flexible prioritization**: Can work on high-priority features first
    51â†’
    52â†’**Trade-offs:**
    53â†’- **More files**: Multiple PRD and progress files to manage
    54â†’- **Cross-feature dependencies**: Must manage dependencies between features manually
    55â†’- **Potential duplication**: Similar patterns may repeat across PRDs
    56â†’
    57â†’## Alternatives Considered
    58â†’
    59â†’### Alternative 1: Single Monolithic PRD
    60â†’**Description:** One large PRD file containing all features and stories.
    61â†’
    62â†’**Rejected because:**
    63â†’- Becomes unwieldy at 1000+ lines
    64â†’- Changes to one feature affect the entire file
    65â†’- Cannot track progress per feature independently
    66â†’- Slower to parse and load
    67â†’
    68â†’### Alternative 2: Hierarchical PRD Structure
    69â†’**Description:** Parent PRD with child PRDs for each feature.
    70â†’
    71â†’**Rejected because:**
    72â†’- Adds complexity without clear benefits
    73â†’- Parent PRD becomes a synchronization point
    74â†’- More difficult to implement and maintain
    75â†’
    76â†’### Alternative 3: Database-Backed PRD Storage
    77â†’**Description:** Store PRDs in a database instead of files.
    78â†’
    79â†’**Rejected because:**
    80â†’- Adds external dependency
    81â†’- More complex to implement
    82â†’- File-based is simpler and more portable
    83â†’
    84â†’## Implementation
    85â†’
    86â†’**PRD File Naming:**
    87â†’- Format: `prd-[feature-name].json`
    88â†’- Example: `prd-user-auth.json`, `prd-task-priority.json`
    89â†’
    90â†’**Progress File Naming:**
    91â†’- Format: `progress-[feature-name].txt`
    92â†’- Example: `progress-user-auth.txt`, `progress-task-priority.txt`
    93â†’
    94â†’**Flow Execution:**
    95â†’```bash
    96â†’/flow start                    # Process all incomplete PRDs
    97â†’/flow status                   # Show status of all PRDs
    98â†’/flow continue [feature-name]  # Continue specific PRD
    99â†’/flow reset [feature-name]     # Reset specific PRD
   100â†’```
   101â†’
   102â†’**Processing Order:**
   103â†’1. Scan `docs/` for all `prd-*.json` files
   104â†’2. Pick first PRD with incomplete stories (alphabetically by filename)
   105â†’3. Process stories in priority order
   106â†’4. When PRD complete, move to next incomplete PRD
   107â†’5. Continue until all PRDs are complete
   108â†’

1â†’# ADR-001: Story-Level MCP Tool Assignment
     2â†’
     3â†’**Status:** Accepted
     4â†’
     5â†’**Date:** 2025-01-11
     6â†’
     7â†’**Last Updated:** 2025-01-11 (Simplified structure)
     8â†’
     9â†’## Context
    10â†’
    11â†’When implementing Maven Flow, we faced a critical decision about how to assign MCP (Model Context Protocol) tools to specialist agents:
    12â†’
    13â†’**Problem:**
    14â†’- If MCP tools are assigned at the PRD level, all stories inherit the same tools
    15â†’- As context grows large during flow execution, agents may "forget" which tools are available
    16â†’- Agents may hallucinate tool availability or use inappropriate tools
    17â†’- Lack of granular control leads to confusion and errors
    18â†’
    19â†’**Observed Issues:**
    20â†’- Agents struggling to identify available tools in large contexts
    21â†’- Inconsistent tool usage across stories
    22â†’- Difficulty debugging which tools should be used for specific tasks
    23â†’
    24â†’## Decision
    25â†’
    26â†’**MCP tools are assigned PER STORY PER STEP in the PRD JSON's `mcpTools` object, NOT at the PRD level.**
    27â†’
    28â†’Each story specifies which MCPs to use for each Maven step:
    29â†’
    30â†’```json
    31â†’{
    32â†’  "id": "US-001",
    33â†’  "title": "Add status field to tasks table",
    34â†’  "mavenSteps": [1, 7],
    35â†’  "mcpTools": {
    36â†’    "step1": ["supabase"],
    37â†’    "step7": ["supabase", "web-search-prime"]
    38â†’  }
    39â†’}
    40â†’```
    41â†’
    42â†’**Key Principles:**
    43â†’1. **Story-level specificity**: Each story lists its exact MCP requirements
    44â†’2. **Step-level granularity**: Different steps may use different MCPs
    45â†’3. **Simple declaration**: Only list MCP names (e.g., "supabase"), not individual tools
    46â†’4. **Agent auto-discovery**: Agents automatically discover available tools from those MCPs
    47â†’
    48â†’**Important:** You only specify the MCP **name**, not individual tools. The agent will automatically discover and use the available tools from that MCP.
    49â†’
    50â†’## Consequences
    51â†’
    52â†’**Benefits:**
    53â†’- **Context Isolation**: Each story has its own specific MCPs, reducing confusion as context grows
    54â†’- **Precision**: Flow command tells agents exactly which MCPs to use for each step
    55â†’- **No Hallucination**: Prevents agents from "forgetting" which MCPs are available in large contexts
    56â†’- **Granular Control**: Different stories and steps can use different MCPs
    57â†’- **Debuggability**: Easy to see which MCPs are available for each story/step
    58â†’- **Simplicity**: No need to list individual tools - just MCP names
    59â†’
    60â†’**Trade-offs:**
    61â†’- **Manual specification**: PRD creators must specify MCPs for each story
    62â†’- **Larger PRD files**: Each story includes MCP configuration
    63â†’
    64â†’## Alternatives Considered
    65â†’
    66â†’### Alternative 1: PRD-Level MCP Assignment
    67â†’**Description:** Assign MCPs once at the PRD level, all stories inherit them.
    68â†’
    69â†’**Rejected because:**
    70â†’- Causes context overload as all stories share the same MCP list
    71â†’- Agents may use inappropriate MCPs for specific tasks
    72â†’- No granular control per story or step
    73â†’
    74â†’### Alternative 2: Individual Tool Listing
    75â†’**Description:** List individual tools within each MCP (e.g., `{ "mcp": "supabase", "tools": ["supabase_query", "supabase_exec"] }`).
    76â†’
    77â†’**Rejected because:**
    78â†’- Over-complicated structure
    79â†’- Agents automatically discover tools from MCPs anyway
    80â†’- More prone to errors when MCP tools change
    81â†’
    82â†’### Alternative 3: Automatic MCP Discovery
    83â†’**Description:** Automatically discover available MCP tools using `claude mcp list` during flow execution.
    84â†’
    85â†’**Rejected because:**
    86â†’- Creates architecture confusion
    87â†’- Agents may hallucinate tool availability in large contexts
    88â†’- Unpredictable behavior as MCP configuration changes
    89â†’
    90â†’## Implementation
    91â†’
    92â†’**PRD JSON Structure:**
    93â†’```json
    94â†’{
    95â†’  "project": "Project Name",
    96â†’  "branchName": "flow/feature-name",
    97â†’  "description": "Feature description",
    98â†’  "userStories": [
    99â†’    {
   100â†’      "id": "US-001",
   101â†’      "title": "Story title",
   102â†’      "description": "As a user, I want feature so that benefit",
   103â†’      "acceptanceCriteria": ["Criterion 1", "Typecheck passes"],
   104â†’      "mavenSteps": [1, 7],
   105â†’      "mcpTools": {
   106â†’        "step1": ["supabase"],
   107â†’        "step7": ["supabase", "web-search-prime"]
   108â†’      },
   109â†’      "priority": 1,
   110â†’      "passes": false,
   111â†’      "notes": ""
   112â†’    }
   113â†’  ]
   114â†’}
   115â†’```
   116â†’
   117â†’**Flow Processing:**
   118â†’1. Read story's `mavenSteps` array (e.g., [1, 7])
   119â†’2. For each step, read story's `mcpTools` for that step (e.g., `mcpTools.step1`)
   120â†’3. Spawn specialist agent and tell them: "Use these MCPs: supabase"
   121â†’4. Agent checks if those MCPs are in their available tools
   122â†’5. Agent uses those MCPs (or falls back to standard tools if unavailable)
   123â†’
   124â†’**Maven Step to Agent Mapping:**
   125â†’| Maven Step | Agent |
   126â†’|------------|-------|
   127â†’| 1, 2, 7, 9 | development-agent |
   128â†’| 3, 4, 6 | refactor-agent |
   129â†’| 5 | quality-agent |
   130â†’| 8, 10 | security-agent |
   131â†’| 11 | design-agent (optional, for mobile) |

1â†’# Maven Flow
     2â†’
     3â†’**Memory-Driven Autonomous AI Development System for Claude Code CLI**
     4â†’
     5â†’Maven Flow is a comprehensive development system that implements PRD stories using a 10-step workflow with specialist agents. Its unique **memory ecosystem** ensures that each new feature learns from previous work, creating an intelligent codebase that accumulates knowledge over time.

    27â†’## Overview
    28â†’
    29â†’Maven Flow combines powerful concepts for autonomous development:
    30â†’
    31â†’| Concept | Description |
    32â†’|---------|-------------|
    33â†’| **Multi-PRD Architecture** | Each feature has its own PRD file, processed independently |
    34â†’| **PRD-Driven Iteration** | Works through user stories one at a time with clean context |
    35â†’| **Maven 10-Step Workflow** | Comprehensive quality assurance via specialized agents |
    36â†’| **Memory Ecosystem** | New features learn from existing implementations |
    37â†’| **Claude Code Native** | Built for Claude Code CLI architecture |
    38â†’
    39â†’### Key Benefits
    40â†’
    41â†’- **Intelligent Context Loading**: Agents receive context from related features
    42â†’- **Feature Relationship Tracking**: Automatic dependency detection and validation
    43â†’- **Accumulated Knowledge**: Each story creates memory, consolidated at PRD completion
    44â†’- **Zero-Tolerance Quality**: Automated hooks enforce standards (no 'any' types, no gradients)
    45â†’- **Multi-Feature Coordination**: Process multiple PRDs in dependency order
    46â†’
    47â†’---
    48â†’
    49â†’## Quick Start
    50â†’
    51â†’```bash
    52â†’# 1. Create a PRD (memory-aware - loads existing context)
    53â†’flow-prd create "I want a payment processing system"
    54â†’
    55â†’# 2. Convert to JSON (analyzes relationships, validates MCPs)
    56â†’flow-convert payments
    57â†’
    58â†’# 3. Start autonomous development (loads related memories)
    59â†’flow start
    60â†’
    61â†’# 4. Check progress
    62â†’flow status
    63â†’```
    64â†’
    65â†’**What happens:**
    66â†’1. **flow-prd** scans existing PRDs, loads consolidated memories, identifies relationships
    67â†’2. **flow-convert** validates MCPs, tags related features, extracts lessons learned
    68â†’3. **flow start** loads related PRD memories + previous story memories before spawning agents
    69â†’

   611â†’## Commands Reference
   612â†’
   613â†’### `/flow start [max-iterations]`
   614â†’
   615â†’Starts autonomous flow execution.
   616â†’
   617â†’```bash
   618â†’/flow start          # Default 10 iterations
   619â†’/flow start 20       # Custom iteration limit
   620â†’/flow start 1        # Process exactly 1 story then stop
   621â†’```
   622â†’
   623â†’**What happens:**
   624â†’1. Validates prerequisites (docs/, PRD files, incomplete stories)
   625â†’2. Scans for all PRD files in `docs/`
   626â†’3. Identifies incomplete stories (`passes: false`)
   627â†’4. For each story:
   628â†’   - **MEMORY LOADING PHASE**: Loads related PRD memories + previous story memories
   629â†’   - **IMPLEMENTATION PHASE**: Spawns specialist agents for each mavenStep
   630â†’   - **QUALITY CHECKS**: Runs typecheck and lint
   631â†’   - **MEMORY CREATION PHASE**: Creates story memory file
   632â†’   - Commits changes with standardized format
   633â†’   - Marks story as complete in PRD
   634â†’5. Continues until max iterations or all PRDs complete
   635â†’

   670â†’### `/flow continue [prd-name] [max-iterations]`
   671â†’
   672â†’Resumes flow execution from where it left off.
   673â†’
   674â†’```bash
   675â†’/flow continue           # Continue with current PRD
   676â†’/flow continue 5         # Continue with 5 more iterations
   677â†’/flow continue auth 10   # Continue specific PRD
   678â†’```
   679â†’
   680â†’### `/flow reset [prd-name]`
   681â†’
   682â†’Archives current PRD run and resets for fresh start.
   683â†’
   684â†’```bash
   685â†’/flow reset           # Prompts to select PRD
   686â†’/flow reset auth      # Reset specific PRD
   687â†’```
   688â†’
   689â†’**What happens:**
   690â†’- Creates archive: `archive/YYYY-MM-DD-[feature-name]/`
   691â†’- Moves current PRD and progress file to archive
   692â†’- Resets all stories to `passes: false`
   693â†’- Creates fresh PRD and progress files
   694â†’- Prompts for confirmation before archiving
   695â†’
   696â†’### `/flow test [prd-name]`
   697â†’
   698â†’Runs comprehensive testing of implemented features.
   699â†’
   700â†’```bash
   701â†’/flow test                    # Test current PRD (auto-detects)
   702â†’/flow test authentication     # Test authentication PRD
   703â†’/flow test task-priority      # Test task-priority PRD
   704â†’```
   705â†’
   706â†’**What happens:**
   707â†’1. Reads PRD to find completed stories
   708â†’2. Starts dev server: `pnpm dev`
   709â†’3. Opens application using chrome-devtools MCP
   710â†’4. Tests user signup/login with standard test user
   711â†’5. Tests each completed feature's acceptance criteria
   712â†’6. Checks console for errors
   713â†’7. Creates error log at `docs/errors-[feature-name].md`

   719â†’### `/flow consolidate [prd-name]`
   720â†’
   721â†’Fixes errors found during testing (without re-implementing features).
   722â†’
   723â†’```bash
   724â†’/flow consolidate            # Consolidate current PRD
   725â†’/flow consolidate auth       # Consolidate authentication PRD
   726â†’```
   727â†’
   728â†’**What happens:**
   729â†’1. Reads error log from `docs/errors-[feature-name].md`
   730â†’2. Identifies which stories/steps have errors
   731â†’3. Re-runs ONLY the affected steps (not entire stories)
   732â†’4. Fixes specific errors found during testing

   740â†’## Terminal Scripts
   741â†’
   742â†’Maven Flow includes terminal forwarder scripts in the `bin/` directory.
   743â†’
   744â†’### Available Scripts
   745â†’
   746â†’| Script | Description | Usage Example |
   747â†’|--------|-------------|---------------|
   748â†’| `flow.sh` / `flow.ps1` / `flow.bat` | Main Maven Flow orchestrator | `flow start 10` |
   749â†’| `flow-prd.sh` / `flow-prd.ps1` / `flow-prd.bat` | PRD creator | `flow-prd create authentication` |
   750â†’| `flow-convert.sh` / `flow-convert.ps1` / `flow-convert.bat` | PRD to JSON converter | `flow-convert authentication` |
   751â†’
   752â†’### Installation
   753â†’
   754â†’**Option 1: Global Installation (Recommended)**
   755â†’```bash
   756â†’# Linux/macOS
   757â†’./bin/flow-install-global.sh
   758â†’source ~/.bashrc  # or restart your terminal
   759â†’
   760â†’# Windows - Add bin/ folder to your PATH manually
   761â†’```
   762â†’
   763â†’**Option 2: Local Installation**
   764â†’```bash
   765â†’# Use scripts directly from bin/ folder
   766â†’./bin/flow.sh start 10
   767â†’./bin/flow-prd.sh create authentication
   768â†’./bin/flow-convert.sh authentication
   769â†’```
   770â†’
   771â†’### Usage Examples
   772â†’
   773â†’**Start autonomous development:**
   774â†’```bash
   775â†’flow start              # Start with default 10 iterations
   776â†’flow start 20           # Start with 20 iterations
   777â†’flow status             # Check progress
   778â†’flow continue           # Resume from last iteration
   779â†’flow reset auth         # Reset specific PRD
   780â†’```
   781â†’
   782â†’**Create and convert PRDs:**
   783â†’```bash
   784â†’# Create a new PRD (markdown)
   785â†’flow-prd create user authentication system with login and signup
   786â†’
   787â†’# Convert to JSON format
   788â†’flow-convert authentication
   789â†’
   790â†’# Start development
   791â†’flow start
   792â†’```

   794â†’### Terminal vs Claude Code Commands
   795â†’
   796â†’The terminal scripts are simple forwarders - they just pass your input to Claude Code:
   797â†’
   798â†’| Terminal Command | Claude Code Command |
   799â†’|------------------|-------------------|
   800â†’| `flow start 10` | `/flow start 10` |
   801â†’| `flow status` | `/flow status` |
   802â†’| `flow-prd create auth` | `/flow-prd create auth` |
   803â†’| `flow-convert auth` | `flow-convert auth` |
   804â†’
   805â†’All the actual work (agent coordination, memory management, context building) is handled by Claude Code commands, not the terminal scripts.

# Maven Flow Codebase Analysis Report

## Summary

The Maven Flow system is a memory-driven autonomous AI development framework with no existing `.stories` directory. It uses a three-layer memory ecosystem (story memory, consolidated memory, and cross-PRD context) that is NOT stored in a centralized `.stories` folder.

---

## 1. PRD JSON Schema

**Location:** `/home/ken/next-mavens-flow/.claude/shared/prd-json-schema.md`

### Complete PRD Structure

```json

  "memorialFile": "string - Path to memorial file: docs/memorial-feature-name.txt",
  "relatedMemorials": [
    "string - Paths to related memorial files"
  ],
  "userStories": [
    {
      "id": "string - US-001, US-002, etc.",
      "title": "string - Story title",
      "description": "string - User story: As a [user], I want [feature] so that [benefit]",
      "acceptanceCriteria": [
        "string - Verifiable criterion",
        "Typecheck passes"
      ],
      "mavenSteps": [number, number],
      "mcpTools": {
        "step1": ["mcp-name-1", "mcp-name-2"],
```

## 3. Current Mutation Patterns

**Location:** `/home/ken/next-mavens-flow/.claude/commands/flow-work-story.md`

### Story Completion Mutation

After a story completes, the flow does:

```bash
# Step 4b: Update PRD - Mark Story Complete
cat "$1" | jq "(.userStories[] | select(.id == \"$2\") | .passes) = true" > tmp.json && mv tmp.json "$1"
```

This updates the PRD JSON to set `passes: true` for the completed story.

### Current Mutation Fields

**What gets mutated:**
1. `userStories[].passes` â†’ Set to `true` when story complete
2. Story memory file â†’ Created with details of implementation

**What does NOT get mutated:**
1. No tracking of which agents were used
2. No recording of what was implemented (file-level)
3. No recording of decisions made
4. No recording of integration points
5. No recording of lessons learned

**What tracks status:**

## Key Findings

1. **No `.stories` directory exists** - Memory is stored in `docs/[feature]/story-*.txt` folders

2. **Related PRD tracking is documented but not implemented** - The ADR-002 and flow-convert.md reference `relatedPRDs` array, but the PRD JSON schema does not include it

3. **Consolidated memory field exists in documentation** - `consolidatedMemory` is mentioned in multiple places but is not in the PRD JSON schema

4. **Lessons learned field is documented** - `lessonsLearned` is referenced in flow-convert.md but not in the PRD JSON schema

5. **Story memory format is incomplete** - The template in create-story-memory.md only captures basic story info, missing crucial implementation details

6. **No story status tracking** - Only `passes: boolean` exists, which is binary (complete/incomplete)

7. **No progress tracking** - No fields track when stories were created or completed, or which mavenSteps have been executed
